name: MACINTOSH II
keyboard: Full stroke 81 keys with numeric keypad and cursor keysOptional extended 105 key keyboard with 15 function keys ($229!)
ram: 1 MB, up to 8 MB on board and 2 GB via NuBus add-on slots
graphics: 640 x 480 (The MAC II uses a NUBUS video card, this card could be replaced with any other more powerful one).
sound: Apple sound chip - 4 voices 1 channel. Can drive external stereo equipment
ports: Six Internal NUBUS slots (10 MHz, 32 bits), ADB (2 : Keyboard, mouse), RS232/422 (2), Disk, Monitor
power: Self configuring switching power supply unit
price: $3769 (1 x 800 KB FDD, 1 MB of RAM)Hard discs: 20 MB ($999), 40 MB ($1599), 80 MB ($2699)
description:
The Apple Macintosh II was launched in 1987 at the same time as the Macintosh SE. It was considered "revolutionary" because, for the first time, the Macintosh was expandable thanks to its internal slots and had colours (the previous Macintoshes all had monochrome displays). The Mac II also marked Apple's entry into the realm of serious computing. 

It used a more classic keyboard (which looked like a PC keyboard) and proprietary RGB monitor (see 'Read more' section). The internal SCSI hard disk could be replaced with an 80 MB disk. It could run under A/UX (The Apple version of Unix System V version 2).

The Macintosh II was followed in September 1988 by the Macintosh IIx. The IIx had the same specifications as the Mac II. It used a 68030 CPU and a 68882 FPU instead of the 68020 and the 68881, an 1.44 MB 3.5" floppy drive and removable system ROMs for easier updates.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</Font></b> SCSI, VIA1, VIA2, SCC and ADB chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</Font></b> 1 to 8 MB RAM in SIMM modules<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</Font></b> 256 KB toolbox ROM<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</Font></b> Memory management custom chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</Font></b> Motorola 68020 processor<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</Font></b> Custom gate array chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</Font></b> 68881 floating-point coprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</Font></b> Apple Sound chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</Font></b> Internal floppy disk connectors<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</Font></b> NuBus control logic<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</Font></b> NuBus tranceivers<br> <b><font color="blue">(12)</Font></b> NuBus slots<br> <b><font color="blue">(13)</Font></b> Internal SCSI connector<br></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTOROLA AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>In fact, this advert didn't promote the Macintosh II computer but the 68020 microprocessor.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...While Apple's choice of the MC 68020 was a smart move, there's no licence on genius: the 68020 is the microprocessor of choice in advanced business system design by such industry leaders as Altos, Alpha Micro, Casio, C.Itoh, Fujitsu, Honneywell Bull, NEC, NCR, Olivetti, Plexus, Ricoh, Sanyo, Sharp, TI, Toshiba and Unisys...</font></blockquote>

emulator.description: Mini vMac, a spin off of the program vMac,  emulates a Macintosh Plus and Macintosh SE. So far it works on Macintosh OS, Microsoft Windows, and the X Window System.
